stance_1: I eat meat less than I used to
stance_2: I eat more chicken than before
justification: The interviewee explicitly states that eating more chicken is part of eating less meat overall.

stance_1: I eat meat less than I used to
stance_2: I plan meals with my wife
justification: Meal planning with his wife implicitly supports their shift toward eating less meat over time.

stance_1: I eat meat less than I used to
stance_2: I believe grilled chicken is healthier than beef
justification: Belief that grilled chicken is healthier supports the conscious shift to eating less (red) meat.

stance_1: I eat meat when I feel like it
stance_2: I plan meals with my wife
justification: Interviewee explicitly mentions that meal planning is based on what they feel like eating.

stance_1: I eat more chicken than before
stance_2: I believe grilled chicken is healthier than beef
justification: Interviewee states they eat more chicken partly due to belief in its health benefits over beef.

stance_1: I only eat ground beef or ground turkey
stance_2: I eat meat when I feel like it
justification: Preference for ground meats aligns with the flexible, as-desired approach to eating meat.

stance_1: I only eat ground beef or ground turkey
stance_2: I plan meals with my wife
justification: The types of meat eaten are influenced by the meals planned with his wife.

stance_1: My children eat chicken and fish
stance_2: I eat more chicken than before
justification: Interviewee notes that both he and his children eat more chicken and fish, indicating parallel and mutually reinforcing habits.

stance_1: My children eat chicken and fish
stance_2: I eat meat less than I used to
justification: The shift in both the interviewee and his children to eating more chicken/fish and less meat suggests mutually supportive changes.
